Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of tragic mask, fragment. Only a portion of the forehead and the upper part of the eyebrows. Mould-made with open back, some hand tool finishing. Traces of fugitive white paint (?) on exterior. Well-levigated Delta silt with a thick gray core with 7.5YR 4/2 (Weak Red) to l0R 5/8 (Red) sandwich. Surfaces mottled from l0R 5/4 (Weak Red) to gray. Finely ground (sand-sized to 1 mm) white, gray, and red grit temper, as well as micaceous inclusions of similar size, are frequent.
Curator's comments: Probably made in Naukratis. Good 3rd to 2nd century BC parallels from Naukratis, including a terracottas workshop, Site 95 (Bailey 2008, no.3567; Petrie et al. 1886, 45; Cambridge, Museum of Classical Archaeology NA718). This was found in a 2nd century BC context at Naukratis (Leonard 2001, pl. 3.2). However, a similar figure was also dated to the 3rd century AD (Fischer 1994: no. 351). Fischer, J. 1994. ‘Griechisch-römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber. Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen’. Tübingen: Wasmuth. Leonard, A. (ed.) 2001. ‘Ancient Naukratis: Excavations at a Greek Emporium, vol. II: The Excavations at Kom Hadid’ ASOR.
Bibliographic references: Leonard 2001 / Ancient Naukratis: Excavations at a Greek Emporion in Egypt, Part II: The excavations at Kom Hadid. (p. 164, no.1 pl. 3.1.)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.311) (Phase 3)
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: pl. 3.1, p. 164. no.1 (catalogue number)
